Acetylcysteine.description: A mucolytic and hepatoprotective agent used in acetaminophen toxicity and respiratory therapy.
Acetylcysteine.contraindications: None specific; avoid in animals with active vomiting if oral.
Acetylcysteine.precautions: Use cautiously in asthmatic animals if inhaled.
Acetylcysteine.ageRestrictions: Safe across all age groups with dose adjustment.

Acepromazine.description: A tranquilizer used for sedation and pre-anesthetic purposes.
Acepromazine.precautions: Use with caution in patients with liver disease.
Acepromazine.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for use in puppies under 6 weeks.

Aceprometazine.description: A phenothiazine tranquilizer used for sedation, often in combination with other agents.
Aceprometazine.precautions: May lower seizure threshold; avoid in aggressive animals without monitoring.
Aceprometazine.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in animals under 8 weeks.

Albendazole.reaction: Anorexia, lethargy, depression, vomiting, diarrhea, elevated liver enzymes, neutropenia, aplastic anemia.
Albendazole.description: A broad-spectrum anthelmintic effective against various nematodes, cestodes, and protozoa.
Albendazole.contraindications: Hypersensitivity to albendazole or other benzimidazoles; use in pregnant animals, especially during the first trimester.
Albendazole.precautions: Use with caution in animals with liver disease; monitor liver function and complete blood counts during prolonged therapy.
Albendazole.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for use in animals under 2 weeks old.

Allopurinol.description: A xanthine oxidase inhibitor used to manage urate urolithiasis and leishmaniasis.
Allopurinol.precautions: Encourage hydration; monitor renal function and urine pH.
Allopurinol.ageRestrictions: Safe in older puppies and adults; avoid in neonates unless necessary.

Amikacin.reaction: Nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, vestibular toxicity (especially in cats)
Amikacin.description: An aminoglycoside antibiotic effective against serious gram-negative infections.
Amikacin.contraindications: Renal insufficiency, preexisting hearing or vestibular damage.
Amikacin.precautions: Monitor renal function and hydration; avoid concurrent nephrotoxic drugs.
Amikacin.ageRestrictions: Use cautiously in neonates due to immature renal clearance.

Amitriptyline.reaction: Sedation, dry mouth, urinary retention, arrhythmias, GI upset, seizures (rare)
Amitriptyline.description: A tricyclic antidepressant used for behavioral disorders, pruritus, and neuropathic pain.
Amitriptyline.contraindications: Use with MAOIs, seizure disorders, or known hypersensitivity.
Amitriptyline.precautions: Use with caution in animals with thyroid, heart, or liver disease.
Amitriptyline.ageRestrictions: Use cautiously in young animals; monitor for adverse behavior changes.

Amphotericin B.description: An antifugal used to treat fungal infections.
Amphotericin B.precautions: Use with caution in patients with renal impairment.
Amphotericin B.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for use in puppies under 8 weeks.

Amoxicillin.description: A broad-spectrum antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections.
Amoxicillin.precautions: Use with caution in patients with renal impairment.
Amoxicillin.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for use in puppies under 8 weeks.

Atenolol.description: A beta-1 selective blocker used for arrhythmias and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Atenolol.contraindications: Bradycardia, AV block, decompensated heart failure.
Atenolol.precautions: Taper off gradually to avoid rebound tachycardia.
Atenolol.ageRestrictions: Adjust dose for juveniles or those with reduced cardiac output.

Atipamezole.description: Alpha-2 antagonist used to reverse sedation from dexmedetomidine.
Atipamezole.precautions: Monitor heart rate and blood pressure.

Atropine.reaction: Dry mouth, increased heart rate, dilated pupils
Atropine.description: An anticholinergic agent used to treat bradycardia and as a pre-anesthetic.
Atropine.precautions: Use with caution in patients with heart disease.
Atropine.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for use in puppies under 6 weeks.

Azathioprine.description: An immunosuppressive agent used to manage immune-mediated diseases in dogs.
Azathioprine.contraindications: Liver dysfunction, pancreatitis, cats (high toxicity risk).
Azathioprine.precautions: Monitor CBC and liver enzymes regularly.
Azathioprine.ageRestrictions: Not recommended in very young or growing animals.

Benazepril.description: An ACE inhibitor used in the treatment of heart failure, proteinuria, and hypertension.
Benazepril.precautions: Monitor kidney values and electrolytes; avoid use with NSAIDs.
Benazepril.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in animals under 8 weeks of age.

Budesonide.reaction: Polyuria, polydipsia, weight gain (mild), GI upset
Budesonide.description: A corticosteroid with low systemic absorption, used for IBD and airway inflammation.
Budesonide.contraindications: Systemic fungal infections, active GI bleeding.
Budesonide.precautions: Taper slowly; monitor for adrenal suppression with long-term use.
Budesonide.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in growing animals.

Butorphanol.reaction: Sedation, ataxia, nausea, respiratory depression (high doses)
Butorphanol.description: An opioid agonist-antagonist used for pain relief and as an antitussive or pre-anesthetic.
Butorphanol.precautions: Use caution with other CNS depressants; monitor respiratory rate.
Butorphanol.ageRestrictions: Use cautiously in neonates and geriatric patients.

Carbamazepine.reaction: Sedation, ataxia, liver enzyme elevation, blood dyscrasias
Carbamazepine.description: An anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer occasionally used off-label in dogs for seizures or neuropathic pain.
Carbamazepine.precautions: Drug interactions common; monitor liver and hematology panels.
Carbamazepine.ageRestrictions: Not typically used in puppies or kittens.

Carprofen.description: A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain relief.
Carprofen.precautions: Use with caution in patients with kidney disease.
Carprofen.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for use in young animals.

Cefalexin.description: An antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections.
Cefalexin.precautions: Use with caution in patients with renal impairment.
Cefalexin.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for use in puppies under 6 weeks.

Cefpodoxime.description: A third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic commonly used in dogs and cats.
Cefpodoxime.precautions: Use cautiously in animals with renal disease.
Cefpodoxime.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in young animals under 8 weeks.

Chlorpheniramine.reaction: Sedation, paradoxical excitement (especially in cats), dry mouth, GI upset
Chlorpheniramine.description: An antihistamine used for allergies, pruritus, and mild sedation.
Chlorpheniramine.precautions: May cause sedation; use with caution with other CNS depressants.
Chlorpheniramine.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in neonates; avoid sustained-release forms in small animals.

Ciprofloxacin.description: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections.
Ciprofloxacin.precautions: Use with caution in patients with renal impairment.
Ciprofloxacin.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for use in puppies under 6 weeks.

Cisapride.description: A promotility agent used in managing GI motility disorders like megacolon in cats.
Cisapride.contraindications: GI obstruction, known arrhythmias, use with CYP3A4 inhibitors.
Cisapride.precautions: Withdrawn from human market due to QT prolongation risk.
Cisapride.ageRestrictions: Safe with appropriate dosing in juveniles.

Clindamycin.reaction: Vomiting, diarrhea, esophagitis in cats, allergic reactions
Clindamycin.description: A lincosamide antibiotic effective against anaerobic bacteria and some protozoa.
Clindamycin.contraindications: Use in rabbits, guinea pigs, horses, and ruminants; known hypersensitivity.
Clindamycin.precautions: Give with water or food in cats to reduce esophageal injury.
Clindamycin.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in neonatal animals; avoid solid tablets in kittens.

Cyproheptadine.reaction: Sedation, dry mouth, increased appetite, paradoxical excitement
Cyproheptadine.description: An antihistamine and serotonin antagonist used for allergies, appetite stimulation, and serotonin syndrome.
Cyproheptadine.precautions: May reduce efficacy of serotonin-based drugs; use cautiously in diabetic patients.
Cyproheptadine.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in very young animals.

Dexamethasone.reaction: Polyuria, polydipsia, increased appetite, GI ulcers, immunosuppression
Dexamethasone.description: A potent corticosteroid used for inflammatory, allergic, and autoimmune conditions.
Dexamethasone.contraindications: Systemic fungal infections, corneal ulcers, GI ulcers.
Dexamethasone.precautions: Taper gradually after prolonged use; monitor for Cushingoid signs.
Dexamethasone.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in young or immunosuppressed animals.

Desoxycorticosterone pivalate (DOCP).reaction: Swelling at injection site, hypernatremia, hypokalemia, GI upset
Desoxycorticosterone pivalate (DOCP).description: A long-acting mineralocorticoid used to treat Addison’s disease (hypoadrenocorticism).
Desoxycorticosterone pivalate (DOCP).precautions: Monitor electrolytes frequently; supplement with glucocorticoid if needed.
Desoxycorticosterone pivalate (DOCP).ageRestrictions: Safe with monitoring in growing dogs.

Diazepam.reaction: Sedation, ataxia, hepatotoxicity (especially in cats), lethargy, appetite stimulation
Diazepam.description: A benzodiazepine used for anxiety, seizures, and muscle relaxation.
Diazepam.contraindications: Severe liver disease, hypersensitivity to benzodiazepines.
Diazepam.precautions: Monitor cats for signs of hepatic failure; avoid long-term use without supervision.
Diazepam.ageRestrictions: Avoid long-term oral use in young cats.

Diclofenac.description: NSAID used topically for equine osteoarthritis.
Diclofenac.precautions: Do not use in food animals.

Diminazene Aceturate.reaction: Injection site pain, fever, hypotension, CNS signs (overdose).

doseRate.dog: 3.5 mg/kg IM/SC once (repeat in 7 days if needed)

Diminazene Aceturate.precautions: Monitor for hypotension; avoid IV (severe reactions).

Doxycycline.description: A broad-spectrum antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections.
Doxycycline.precautions: Use with caution in patients with renal impairment.
Doxycycline.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for use in puppies under 8 weeks.

Enrofloxacin.reaction: Vomiting, diarrhea, cartilage damage in young animals, CNS effects (seizures), ocular toxicity in cats
Enrofloxacin.description: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic effective against a broad range of gram-negative and some gram-positive bacteria.
Enrofloxacin.contraindications: Use in young, growing animals; known hypersensitivity to fluoroquinolones.
Enrofloxacin.precautions: Avoid use with antacids, dairy, or iron supplements. Use with caution in animals with CNS disorders.
Enrofloxacin.administrationRoute: Oral, Injectable (IM, IV in some cases)
Enrofloxacin.ageRestrictions: Not recommended in dogs <8 months; cats max dose 5 mg/kg/day due to risk of blindness.

Epinephrine.description: Alpha- and beta-adrenergic agonist for anaphylaxis and cardiac arrest.
Epinephrine.ageRestrictions: No specific age restrictions in emergencies.

Erythromycin.description: A macrolide antibiotic used in GI motility and infection control (e.g. Rhodococcus equi in foals).
Erythromycin.precautions: Do not use in adult horses due to colitis risk.
Erythromycin.ageRestrictions: Use with extreme caution in neonates due to GI effects.

Famotidine.description: An H2-receptor antagonist used to reduce stomach acid and treat ulcers.
Famotidine.precautions: May reduce absorption of drugs needing acidic environment (e.g., ketoconazole).
Famotidine.ageRestrictions: Generally safe across age groups; monitor in neonates with renal compromise.

Furosemide.description: A loop diuretic used to treat edema, congestive heart failure, and other fluid-retention conditions.
Furosemide.precautions: Ensure adequate water intake; monitor electrolyte levels regularly.
Furosemide.ageRestrictions: Not recommended in very young animals without close monitoring.

Gabapentin.reaction: Sedation, ataxia, vomiting, lethargy; possible false positive urine protein tests
Gabapentin.description: An anticonvulsant and analgesic used for neuropathic pain and refractory seizures.
Gabapentin.contraindications: Hypersensitivity to gabapentin. Use oral solution cautiously in dogs due to xylitol content.
Gabapentin.precautions: Use with caution in renal impairment; may interact with antacids, hydrocodone, and morphine.
Gabapentin.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in pediatric patients; monitor for sedation.

Gentamicin.reaction: Nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity (especially in cats), gastrointestinal disturbances, weakness, restlessness
Gentamicin.description: An aminoglycoside antibiotic effective against many aerobic gram-negative and some gram-positive bacteria.
Gentamicin.precautions: Monitor kidney function and hydration status closely. Avoid combining with other nephrotoxic drugs.
Gentamicin.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in neonates due to immature renal function.

Hydroxyzine.reaction: Sedation, dry mouth, tremors, seizures (rare), polydipsia, depression (in cats)
Hydroxyzine.description: An antihistamine used for allergies, pruritus, and anxiety in dogs and cats.
Hydroxyzine.contraindications: Prostatic hypertrophy, bladder neck obstruction, angle-closure glaucoma, cardiac failure.
Hydroxyzine.precautions: Use cautiously with CNS depressants and anticholinergics. May mask symptoms in allergy testing.
Hydroxyzine.ageRestrictions: Avoid use in pregnant animals unless necessary.

Imidocarb.reaction: Pain at injection site, cholinergic signs, nephrotoxicity
Imidocarb.description: Antiprotozoal used to treat babesiosis and other tick-borne infections.
Imidocarb.precautions: Pre-treat with atropine to reduce side effects.
Imidocarb.ageRestrictions: Avoid in very young animals unless necessary.

Insulin (Glargine).description: Long-acting insulin used in the management of diabetes mellitus.
Insulin (Glargine).ageRestrictions: Use with caution in pediatric animals.

Isoflurane.description: A volatile inhalant anesthetic used for maintenance of general anesthesia.
Isoflurane.precautions: Monitor respiration and cardiac function continuously.
Isoflurane.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in very young or geriatric patients.

Ivermectin.description: An antiparasitic used to treat various parasitic infections.
Ivermectin.precautions: Use with caution in collies and other sensitive breeds.
Ivermectin.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for use in young animals.

Ketamine.reaction: Increased heart rate, salivation, muscle rigidity, hallucinations (in recovery)
Ketamine.description: A dissociative anesthetic used in combination protocols for induction or sedation.
Ketamine.precautions: Avoid use alone for major procedures; combine with muscle relaxants.
Ketamine.ageRestrictions: Use cautiously in neonates due to variable metabolism.

Ketoconazole.description: An antifungal agent used to treat systemic and superficial fungal infections.
Ketoconazole.precautions: Monitor liver enzymes; administer with food to improve absorption.
Ketoconazole.ageRestrictions: Not recommended in young or debilitated animals without veterinary supervision.

Levamisole.reaction: Hypersalivation, tremors, seizures, GI upset, dyspnea, ataxia
Levamisole.description: An anthelmintic and immune stimulant used primarily in ruminants and swine.
Levamisole.contraindications: Do not use in dairy animals of breeding age; avoid IV administration.
Levamisole.precautions: Toxicity signs resemble organophosphate poisoning; avoid combining with similar drugs.
Levamisole.ageRestrictions: Avoid in debilitated or young animals; use with caution.

Lidocaine.reaction: CNS depression, vomiting, seizures (high dose), cardiac depression
Lidocaine.description: A local anesthetic and antiarrhythmic agent used for nerve blocks and ventricular arrhythmias.
Lidocaine.precautions: Toxicity more likely in cats; dose carefully.
Lidocaine.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in pediatric patients.

Lorazepam.description: Benzodiazepine used for anxiety, seizures, and sedation.
Lorazepam.precautions: Can cause dependence with long-term use.

Maropitant.description: NK1 receptor antagonist used to prevent and treat vomiting.

Meloxicam.description: A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain relief.
Meloxicam.precautions: Use with caution in patients with kidney disease.
Meloxicam.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for use in young animals.

Methimazole.reaction: Vomiting, facial pruritus, hepatopathy, blood dyscrasias in cats
Methimazole.description: An antithyroid drug used to manage feline hyperthyroidism.
Methimazole.precautions: Monitor CBC and liver enzymes regularly; may need dose adjustments.
Methimazole.ageRestrictions: Generally safe in adult cats; monitor closely in geriatrics.

Metoclopramide.reaction: Sedation, agitation, extrapyramidal effects, diarrhea, restlessness
Metoclopramide.description: A dopamine antagonist and prokinetic used for nausea, vomiting, and delayed gastric emptying.
Metoclopramide.precautions: Avoid use with MAOIs; may enhance CNS depressant effects.
Metoclopramide.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in young or geriatric patients.

Metronidazole.reaction: Anorexia, vomiting, neurologic signs (ataxia, seizures), hepatotoxicity
Metronidazole.description: An antibiotic and antiprotozoal used to treat anaerobic infections and Giardia.
Metronidazole.contraindications: Pregnancy (especially 1st trimester), liver disease, hypersensitivity to nitroimidazoles.
Metronidazole.precautions: Monitor for neurologic side effects during long-term use; bitter taste may reduce compliance.
Metronidazole.ageRestrictions: Avoid in very young animals without veterinary supervision.

Midazolam.reaction: Sedation, ataxia, respiratory depression, paradoxical excitation (rare)
Midazolam.description: A benzodiazepine used for sedation, anesthesia premedication, and seizure control.
Midazolam.contraindications: Severe respiratory depression, hypersensitivity to benzodiazepines.
Midazolam.precautions: Monitor respiration and cardiovascular function closely.
Midazolam.ageRestrictions: Safe in neonates with dose adjustment.

Milbemycin oxime.reaction: Lethargy, vomiting, ataxia, especially in herding breeds (MDR1 mutation)
Milbemycin oxime.description: An antiparasitic used for prevention of heartworm disease and control of intestinal worms.
Milbemycin oxime.contraindications: Known hypersensitivity, caution in MDR1 mutation breeds.
Milbemycin oxime.precautions: Genetic testing for MDR1 advised in collies and similar breeds.
Milbemycin oxime.ageRestrictions: Approved for puppies and kittens over 6 weeks.

Misoprostol.reaction: Diarrhea, abdominal pain, uterine cramping, vomiting
Misoprostol.description: A synthetic prostaglandin E1 analog used to prevent/treat NSAID-induced gastric ulcers.
Misoprostol.precautions: Handle with gloves, especially by pregnant women.
Misoprostol.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in young animals; dose adjust if needed.

Morphine.description: Full opioid agonist for pain management and sedation.
Morphine.precautions: Monitor respiratory rate; use lowest effective dose.
Morphine.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in neonates and geriatrics.

Moxidectin.description: Macrocyclic lactone for parasite control (e.g. heartworms, mites).
Moxidectin.precautions: Monitor for neurotoxicity at high doses.
Moxidectin.ageRestrictions: Not for use in animals under 6 weeks.

Neomycin.description: Aminoglycoside antibiotic used topically and orally for GI infections.
Neomycin.precautions: Avoid systemic use due to toxicity.
Neomycin.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in young animals.

Naltrexone.description: Opioid antagonist used to reverse opioid effects.
Naltrexone.precautions: Titrate to effect in opioid-dependent animals.
Naltrexone.ageRestrictions: Caution in very young or old patients.

Omeprazole.reaction: GI upset, constipation or diarrhea, possible liver enzyme changes
Omeprazole.description: A proton pump inhibitor used to treat gastric ulcers and esophagitis.
Omeprazole.contraindications: Hypersensitivity to omeprazole or other PPIs.
Omeprazole.precautions: May alter absorption of other oral medications; use with caution in hepatic impairment.
Omeprazole.ageRestrictions: Generally safe; consider lower doses for neonates.

Oxytetracycline.reaction: GI distress, staining of teeth/bones, superinfections, photosensitivity, uroliths (long-term use), ruminal stasis (ruminants), local reactions (IM).
Oxytetracycline.description: Tetracycline antibiotic used for mycoplasma, rickettsia, spirochetes, and Chlamydia infections.
Oxytetracycline.precautions: Avoid rapid IV (hemolysis risk); monitor renal/liver function.

Oxytocin.description: Hormone used to induce labor or milk let-down.
Oxytocin.precautions: Ensure cervix is dilated before administration.

Paracetamol.description: Non-opioid analgesic and antipyretic used cautiously in dogs; highly toxic to cats.
Paracetamol.precautions: Monitor liver enzymes; avoid repeated dosing.
Paracetamol.ageRestrictions: Not recommended for young puppies or kittens.

Penicillin.reaction: Allergic reactions, GI upset, neurotoxicity at high doses
Penicillin.description: Beta-lactam antibiotic effective against gram-positive bacteria.
Penicillin.precautions: Avoid IV in small animals for some forms.

Phenobarbital.description: Barbiturate anticonvulsant used for epilepsy management.
Phenobarbital.precautions: Monitor liver enzymes during long-term use.
Phenobarbital.ageRestrictions: Use with caution in neonates and geriatrics.

Praziquantel.description: Anthelmintic used against tapeworms in dogs and cats.
Praziquantel.ageRestrictions: Not for use in animals under 4 weeks old.

Promethazine.reaction: Sedation, dry mouth, hypotension, GI upset.

Pyrantel.description: Anthelmintic used to treat hookworms and roundworms.
Pyrantel.precautions: Shake suspensions well; use exact weight for dosing.
Pyrantel.ageRestrictions: Safe in puppies and kittens >2 weeks old.

Tramadol.description: Analgesic used for moderate to severe pain management.
Tramadol.precautions: Not a substitute for NSAIDs in acute pain; efficacy varies in dogs.
Tramadol.ageRestrictions: Caution in pediatric and geriatric patients.

Tylosin.description: Macrolide antibiotic used for chronic colitis and respiratory infections.
Tylosin.precautions: Avoid IM in small dogs due to pain.

Vitamin B12 (Cyanocobalamin).description: Essential for hematopoiesis and neurologic function.

doseRate.cat: 0.1–0.3 mg/kg IM/SC (rarely used due to sensitivity)

Xylazine.description: Alpha-2 agonist for sedation, analgesia, muscle relaxation.
